chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Fertility awareness methods
chapter.summary: Covers advice on using fertility awareness methods, the advantages, disadvantages, risks, and efficacy.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 13 years to 60 years (Female).

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman who is planning to use a fertility awareness method of contraception?
subChapters.htmlStringContent: • For information on the assessment of a woman who is planning to use a fertility awareness method of contraception, see the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: What medical conditions may make fertility awareness methods of contraception less suitable?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• There are no medical conditions which become worse due to the use of fertility awareness methods (FAM) and generally, these methods can be used without concern.
  • However, several conditions can make the use of the mucus (cervical secretion and cycle length) FAM and the device methods more complex. 
    • Menstrual and cycle irregularities.
    • Postpartum – in the first 4 weeks postpartum, there are unlikely to be any detectable fertility signs or hormonal changes.
    • Recent use of hormonal contraception – the menstrual cycle may be altered. 
    • Drugs – antibiotics (such as tetracyclines), cold remedies and analgesics may affect fertility indicators.
  • Women with medical conditions (such as Eisenmenger syndrome), or taking certain medicines (such as teratogenic drugs), which make pregnancy an unacceptable risk should be advised that fertility awareness methods may not be appropriate for them because other methods of contraception have lower failure rates with typical use.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Fertility Awareness Methods [FSRH, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What information and advice should I give to a woman who is considering using fertility awareness methods of contraception?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Give advice and information about:
    • The need to receive counselling, training, and ongoing support from someone trained to teach natural family planning. 
    • The advantages, disadvantages, and risks of the fertility awareness methods. See the section on What are the advantages, disadvantages, and risks of fertility awareness methods of contraception?
    • The efficacy of fertility awareness methods. See the section on How effective are the fertility awareness methods at preventing pregnancy?
    • Alternative methods of contraception, taking into account her personal, cultural, and religious beliefs.
    • The comparative efficacy of alternative methods of contraception. See the section on Comparative efficacy of contraceptive methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment. 
    • Where to purchase or seek accurate information about fertility monitoring devices. 
    • Sources of additional information:
      • The Family Planning Association provides a useful leaflet, Your guide to natural family planning, which has information for users of the fertility awareness methods (and other methods of contraception).
      • Brook Advisory Centres provide sexual health services and advice for people under the age of 25.
  • If the woman has a condition which makes pregnancy an unacceptable risk, advise her that the fertility awareness methods of contraception may not be appropriate, as alternative contraceptive methods have lower failure rates. See the section on How should I assess a woman who is considering using Natural Family Planning methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Fertility Awareness Methods [FSRH, 2015] and expert opinion from a medical textbook, The essentials of contraceptive technology: a handbook for clinic staff [Hatcher et al, 1997].

subChapters.htmlHeader: What are the advantages, disadvantages, and risks of fertility awareness methods of contraception?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Advantages
  • They can be used by most couples.
  • They do not involve use of chemicals or physical products.
  • There are no physical or hormonal adverse effects.
  • There are no contraindications to their use. 
  • They can help the woman recognize normal and abnormal vaginal secretions.
  • They involve men in the process and can help the woman to communicate about her fertility and sexuality.
  • They are acceptable to all faiths and cultures.
  • Initial and continuing costs can be low. 
  • They are immediately reversible.

Disadvantages
  • They are only moderately effective compared to other methods.
  • They require continuing cooperation and commitment of both partners. 
  • To be optimally effective, they must be taught by someone trained to teach natural family planning.
  • It takes two or three menstrual cycles to learn how to identify the fertile time accurately using cervical secretions and basal body temperature. 
  • They are not suitable for women with irregular cycles.
  • Fertility indicators must be monitored and recorded daily.
  • Illness, lifestyle, stress, travel, and use of hormonal treatments can make fertility indicators hard to interpret.
  • During the fertile time, other contraceptive methods (such as barrier methods) may need to be used or abstinence practised for 8–16 days during each menstrual cycle.
  • Indicators of fertility are unreliable in women who are breastfeeding.
  • Natural methods do not protect against sexually transmitted infections, including HIV.
  • Couples may need to avoid sexual intercourse (during the fertile period) which some people may find difficult.
  • Some devices and consumables must be purchased and they can be expensive.
Risks
  • Fertility awareness methods in themselves carry no health risks to users. However, women with medical conditions that could make pregnancy high risk should consider other, more effective contraceptive methods.
[Hatcher et al, 1997; Frank-Herrmann et al, 2007; FSRH, 2015]

subChapters.htmlHeader: How effective are the fertility awareness methods at preventing pregnancy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
For comparison of the efficacy of fertility awareness methods with other methods of contraception, see the section on Comparative efficacy of contraceptive methods in the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment.

  • When used perfectly (consistently and correctly), 1-9% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure.
  • When used typically, 24% of women will conceive within the first year of use due to method failure or user failure.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
This information is based on the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Fertility Awareness Methods [FSRH, 2015] and information from a medical textbook, Contraceptive technology [Hatcher, 2011]. 

  • There is limited good-quality evidence investigating the efficacy of fertility awareness methods (FAM) of contraception [FSRH, 2015]:   
    • A Cochrane systematic review of three randomized controlled trials (RCTs) was unable to determine pregnancy rates associated with FAM, so the exact efficacy is very difficult to ascertain.
      • The RCTs were of poor quality with high drop-out rates [Grimes, 2004].
